title: 104_hr3738
content: The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 is amended to reduce the extended benefits trigger from 5% to 4%. The effective date for these amendments is 6 months after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for increasing or decreasing earnings credited to state accounts based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 is amended to reduce the extended benefits trigger from 5% to 4%. The Social Security Act is also amended to adjust earnings credited to state accounts based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. If a State's average daily balance in the Unemployment Trust Fund exceeds the funding goal, an interest premium is applied, and if it falls below, an interest penalty is imposed. The interest premium or penalty cannot exceed $2,500,000 in any calendar quarter. The Secretary will adjust interest premiums if they exceed penalties. Interest penalty is defined as the excess of the funding goal over the average daily balance in the State account. The Secretary will adjust interest premiums based on the funding goal of each State's Unemployment Trust Fund account. The funding goal is calculated as the average of unemployment insurance benefits paid by the State over a 20-year period. The text discusses the calculation of the funding goal for each State's Unemployment Trust Fund account based on the average unemployment benefits paid over a 20-year period. It also defines the term 'percentage value' in relation to the excess balance in the State account. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding the crediting of state accounts and the interest rate on repayment of advances. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes to the calculation of funding goals for State Unemployment Trust Fund accounts and the crediting of interest premiums. A report recommending funding sources for interest premiums is required within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The amendments will be effective for calendar years starting after December 31, 1996. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes to State Unemployment Trust Fund funding goals and interest-free advances. The effective date for these changes is calendar years beginning after December 31, 1996. Additionally, there are provisions for State collection of Federal Unemployment Tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes to State Unemployment Trust Fund funding goals and interest-free advances. The effective date for these changes is calendar years beginning after December 31, 1996. Additionally, there are provisions for State collection of Federal Unemployment Tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3311 addresses State collection of tax. Each State certified under section 3304 can elect to have employers submit the tax imposed by this chapter with respect to wages to the State instead of the Secretary. Payment to the State is considered timely if made alongside contributions to the State's unemployment fund. If the tax payment is not made on time, the exception in subsection (c) applies. The State must transmit the Federal tax to the Secretary after making the election. The State, certified under section 3304, can elect to have employers submit the tax to the Secretary or the State. The Secretary may require additional information from the State regarding the tax payable by employers. The table of sections for chapter 23 is amended accordingly. The State can choose to collect taxes under section 3311 or 3312. Amendments made by this section apply to taxable years after December 31, 1996. Section 3304 is amended to require States to distribute information packets on unemployment insurance eligibility. This amendment applies to State certifications for 1997, with exceptions for States whose legislatures do not meet in 1997.
